subject: Form Element setting issue
msgSnippet: Hi, I am getting the following exception when i try to set a Form element. input type is File testTitleSearch(JWebUnitLogin): Attempted to assign to parameter
messageBody:
Hi,

I am getting the following exception when i try to set
a Form element.

input type is File

testTitleSearch(JWebUnitLogin): Attempted to assign to
parameter 'theFile1' the extraneous value
'C:\CdimCiti\FileMoved\cdim_demo.txt'.

Also can somebody tell me how to set the test
environment using jUnit if it can be done.

Regards,
Gunjeet

--- "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@...> wrote:
---------------------------------

>So said jxingtang on 2003-07-30 --------------------
>> >A further question for StringWriter manipulation.
Since I have to
>> >test several methods with console output which
share the same
>> >StringWriter wrapped in the PrinterWriter. The
problem is how to
>> >clean up the buffer after one test case. flush()
method seems not
>> >work as expected.
>>
>> Why do you have to share the same StringWriter for
each test? Just
>create a new one.

>I have found a way to solve the problem. I calls the
getBuffer()to
>get the string buffer from the StringWriter and
delete its content.
>
>The reason for me to share the StringWriter is that I
do not want to
>construct a new class instance being tested for each
method. I only
>construct on in setUp(). Here are of my code
snippets.

I have news for you: setUp() is called for each test.
You are creating the extra StringWriter every time,
anyway.

Don't worry about it. These aren't performance tests.
Just create a new one each time.

>public class MyClass
>{
> private PrintWriter MyWriter;
>
> // Constructor for production release
> public MyClass()
> {
> MyWriter = new PrintWriter( System.out );
> }
>
> // Constructor for Junit testing
> public MyClass( PrintWriter pw )
> {
> MyWriter = pw;
> }
>
> public void DumpOutput( Vector params )
> {
> // Clip ...
> }
>};
>
>public class MyClassTest extends TestCase
>{
> private MyClass MyTestObj = null;
>
> private StringWriter StrWriter = null;
>
> // Clip ...
>
> protected void setUp()
> {
> StrWriter = new StringWriter();
> PrintWriter prWriter = new PrintWriter(
StrWriter );
> TestObj = new MyClass( prWriter );
> }
>
> public DumpOutputTest()
> {
> Vector testParams = new Vector();
> // Testcase 1
> testParams.addElement( "A" );
> testParams.addElement( "B" );
> testParams.addElement( "C" );
>
> TestObj.DumpOutput( testParams );
>
> String outStr = StrWriter.toString();
>
> // Code to evaluate outStr
> // Clip ....
>
> // Clean buffer of StringWriter
> StringBuffer sbuff = StrWriter.getBuffer();
> sbuff.delete( 0, outStr.length());
>
> // Testcase 2
> testParams.addElement( "X" );
> testParams.addElement( "Y" );
> testParams.addElement( "Z" );
>
> TestObj.DumpOutput( testParams );
>
> String outStr = StrWriter.toString();
>
> // Code to evaluate outStr
> // Clip ....
> }
>
> // Clip ...
>};
>
>Please give your valuable comments for my further
correction and
>improvements.

Why are you writing multiple tests in a single method?
Each test should be its own method. You defeat the
point of JUnit by using it this way.

Take care.

'
